Headline.Para: What'sTrending; Dark side of Reddit and a false claim

LeadPara.Para: Online toxic communities hard to police; and that post on checking safety of account is false
A string of controversial images and videos has brought the shadier parts of social news aggregator Reddit to the fore in recent weeks.

TailParas.Para: NoMorals, a forum dedicated to making fun of mutilated or dead people including children, and animals, was reported by online news site Motherboard on March 6 as actively promoting disturbing content.
One of the rules of this particular "subreddit'' was that users could post whatever they wanted, "so long as it was funny".

"It could be a smashed guy, a bloated lady, a dead cat with a pop tart, anything. It's half the fun, you see a funny title, you match it with a picture," the rule said. One of the top posts among its 19,000 subscribers was a video of a man set aflame, accompanied by a joke.
Reddit co-founder Steve Huffman said earlier he was aware of the subreddit's activities after being warned that it contained what the guidelines deemed unacceptable content.

Toxic communities have been highlighted before but the policing has been inconsistent, in part due to the organic and secretive nature of the site. For instance, more than 500 new subreddits are created each day, on a range of topics from uncovering rare vintage garments to hidden passion for "forbidden snacks" like clay.

A post by user Remee Dayao-Centeno, which shows Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, claiming that typing"BFF" in a comment can indicate if your account is safe, has been debunked by fact-checking site Snopes. PHOTO: FACEBOOK
NoMorals was deleted, however, only after the Motherboard report was released.
Around the same time, another video - of what appears to be a man shooting himself streamed live on YouTube - was a top post on a subreddit titled Drama, which has more than 51,000 subscribers.
Although it contravened Reddit's content policy, it was up for more than 10 hours before being taken down.
It was also posted on another subreddit dedicated to watching people in the last moments of their lives.
The post generated a fair amount of discussion. Critics said the subreddit's moderators, who are mostly volunteers, did not act fast enough to take down the content.

Proponents said the forum was a place for users to view the horrors of the world. "It should not be seen as a place that encourages violence but rather as one that wards us from violence," said user RetroArchitect.
"Death is real, and this is a constant reminder of that.To remove this sub would be to try to bury reality.
"Even if this sub is surrounded by death, I believe its outward effect on Reddit and its users is undeniably positive," he added.
Another user, a paramedic working in emergency medical services, said the subreddit was helpful in preparing him for the harsh reality his job entails.

With fake news dominating the headlines as big players grapple with verifying information, the developments in Reddit also highlight another pressing issue.
Controversial content is more likely to be shared quickly, and some social networks seemingly do not have the resources to take remedial action.
THE GREEN BFF IS FAKE
Regular Facebook users might have seen posts in the past week saying that typing "BFF" in a comment can indicate if your account is safe.
If it appears green, the claim goes, your account is protected.
If it does not, then it is time to change your password immediately because there is a high chance of your account being hacked.
The original post by user Remee Dayao-Centeno, which shows a photo of Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, has been shared more than 14,000 times.
Fact-checking site Snopes has investigated the claim and has determined it to be false.
"BFF" is part of a feature called Text Delight, which automatically animates certain words. The list includes other terms such as "Congratulations", "Best Wishes", "xoxo" and "You Got This".

"'BFF' appearance (or lack thereof) is not related to account security in any way. A missing green 'BFF' does not indicate anyone's account was compromised at any point, and instead most likely relates to browser settings," Snopes added.
Users are encouraged to read up on such feature developments, rather than accepting the "truth" of a viral post wholesale.
